description:
Odocoileus virginianus texanus, commonly known as the Texas white-tailed deer, is a subspecies of the white-tailed deer (Odocoileus virginianus) that is native to the state of Texas in the United States.

The Texas white-tailed deer is a medium-sized ungulate characterized by its distinctive white-tailed appearance. It has a compact and muscular build, with a distinctive reddish-brown coat during the summer that transitions to a grayer hue in the winter. The deer's most distinguishing feature is its large, fan-shaped white tail, which it prominently displays when alarmed or fleeing.

This subspecies is adapted to the diverse ecosystems found in Texas, ranging from the arid regions of the western part of the state to the more humid and forested regions of the east. They are highly adaptable and can thrive in a variety of habitats, including grasslands, woodlands, and even urban areas.

The Texas white-tailed deer plays an important ecological role in their native range, serving as a prey species for various predators and contributing to the overall biodiversity of the region. They are also a popular game species, with their hunting closely regulated by state wildlife management agencies to ensure the sustainability of the population.
